JavaScript Exams Schedule - Semester 1, Academic Year 2023-2024

Group Exam Type Date and Time Room
120, 118, 321 Main 25.01.2024, 10:00 M308, D339, S343
229 Main 28.01.2024, 14:00 I308, V339
298, 275, 277 Main 09.02.2024, 11:00 H308, B336, B307, B320
All Groups Retake 19.02.2024, 15:00 B336, B339, C343

Notes

  • If you need to present on a secondary date, please use one of the exam dates for the other groups;
  • The exam for group 225 could not be scheduled in Academic Info;
  • Students from the Mathematical Informatics specialization are requested to attend the exam with the group they attended the lab with.

At the Beginning of the Semester

  • Please join the team with the code 'mksdlaws';
  • Remember, learning is a journey, not a race. Students from various backgrounds are allowed a maximum of 2 attendances in a laboratory. Choose your laboratory subgroup within the first two weeks of classes.;
  • Students from other specializations (Mathematics in Romanian), other faculties, and retake students will be accepted a maximum of 2 times in a laboratory. These students are requested to choose the laboratory subgroup they will attend (the same throughout the semester) in the first 2 weeks of the teaching activities;
  • Students from the specializations Mathematics in English or Computer Science in English are kindly asked to attend the course and laboratories coordinated by Assoc. Prof. Dr. John Doe (Computer Networks, MLE5002).

Requirements and Evaluation Method

  • Weekly Quizzes:
    • Multiple-choice and short-answer questions to assess understanding of theoretical concepts.
    • Graded on a scale of 0-10.
  • Assignments:
    • Code quality, correctness, and adherence to best practices.
    • Graded on a scale of 0-20.
  • Exams:
    • Mid-term and final projects will be evaluated based on functionality, code organization, creativity, and adherence to project requirements.
    • Graded on a scale of 0-30.
  • Final Project:
    • Final projects will be evaluated based on functionality, code organization, creativity, and adherence to project requirements.
    • Graded on a scale of 0-30.
  • Participation:
    • Active participation in class discussions, Q&A sessions, and online forums.
    • Graded on a scale of 0-10.
  • Overall Assessments:
    • Total points will be calculated based on the sum of quiz, assignment, project, and participation scores.

Course Objectives

  • Understand the fundamental principles of relational databases.
  • Demonstrate proficiency in writing SQL queries to retrieve, update, and manipulate data.
  • Design and implement normalized database schemas.
  • Utilize advanced SQL features for complex queries, transactions, and optimization.
  • Implement database security measures and understand best practices.
  • Apply SQL concepts in real-world scenarios and projects.

Course content

Module Topic
1 Introduction to Relational Databases and SQL Basics
2 Advanced SQL Querrying and Filtering
3 Database Design and Normalization
4 Transactions and Advanced Concepts
5 Arrays and associative arrays
6 Database Security
7 Real-world applications and integration
